verses.text: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by command of God our Savior and Christ Jesus our hope,
verses.comment: Paul declares his authority comes from both God and Christ Jesus, showing the unity between the Father and the Son. The explicit mention of 'our Savior' and 'our hope' lays a foundation for understanding salvation as rooted in both divine persons, a theme echoed through the New Testament.

verses.text: To Timothy, my true child in faith: Grace, mercy, and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.comment: Paul refers to Timothy with fatherly affection, highlighting the significance of spiritual mentorship and continuity in the Church. The triple blessing—grace, mercy, and peace—reflects a fullness found in Trinitarian relationships.

verses.text: As I urged you when I went to Macedonia, stay in Ephesus so that you may command certain people not to teach different doctrines,
verses.comment: Paul’s concern for doctrinal purity points to the importance of authoritative teaching and apostolic succession within the Church, ensuring the faith is preserved from corruption.

verses.text: nor to devote themselves to myths and endless genealogies, which promote speculations rather than the stewardship from God that is by faith.
verses.comment: Paul contrasts vain speculation with faithful stewardship. The primacy of faith and proper Church order is emphasized over private interpretation.

verses.text: The goal of our command is love that comes from a pure heart, a good conscience, and sincere faith.
verses.comment: Love is shown as the fruit of right doctrine—linked to purity, conscience, and sincerity—drawing attention to the inward formation expected of believers.

verses.text: Some, having strayed from these, have turned aside to meaningless talk.
verses.comment: Deviation from apostolic teaching leads to fruitless conversation, emphasizing the need for fidelity to the apostolic tradition.

verses.text: They desire to be teachers of the law, though they do not understand what they are saying or the things about which they make confident assertions.
verses.comment: Warning against self-appointed teachers lacking true understanding, Paul underscores that authority and proper interpretation rests with those taught and appointed within the Church.

verses.text: Now we know that the law is good, if one uses it properly.
verses.comment: The law’s goodness is affirmed, provided it is rightly understood and applied. This points to the legitimate role of tradition and ecclesial interpretation in unfolding the fullness of the law.

verses.text: We also know that the law is not made for the righteous but for the lawless and rebellious, for the ungodly and sinful, for the unholy and profane, for those who kill father or mother, for murderers,
verses.comment: The law exposes sin, highlighting the need for grace. Reference to honoring parents and prohibition of murder directly echoes the Ten Commandments.

verses.text: for sexually immoral, for those who practice homosexuality, for enslavers, for liars, for perjurers, and for whatever else is contrary to sound teaching
verses.comment: Paul lists forms of immorality condemned in Scripture, reinforcing continuity between Old and New Testament moral teaching. 'Sound teaching' presupposes a trustworthy deposit of faith.

verses.text: according to the gospel of the glory of the blessed God, which has been entrusted to me.
verses.comment: Paul’s stewardship of the gospel signals a tradition handed down and guarded, reflecting the apostolic office.

verses.text: I thank Christ Jesus our Lord, who has enabled me, because he considered me faithful, appointing me to his service,
verses.comment: Paul sees his calling as rooted in Christ’s choice and grace. The act of divine appointment highlights the necessity of a legitimate ministry.

verses.text: though I was formerly a blasphemer, persecutor, and violent man. But I received mercy because I acted ignorantly in unbelief.
verses.comment: Paul refers to his former hostility, pointing to transformative grace. Mercy is shown to those whose ignorance can be overcome through divine enlightenment.

verses.text: And the grace of our Lord overflowed for me, with the faith and love that are in Christ Jesus.
verses.comment: Emphasizing superabundant grace, Paul links faith and love as gifts found in union with Christ.

verses.text: The saying is trustworthy and deserving full acceptance: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners—of whom I am the foremost.
verses.comment: Paul summarizes the mission of Christ as saving sinners. This underscores both the universality of grace and the efficacy of Christ’s redemptive work. Spiritual humility is modeled here.

verses.text: But for this reason I received mercy, so that in me, as the foremost, Christ Jesus might display his perfect patience, as an example for those who would believe in him for eternal life.
verses.comment: Paul’s life becomes a living witness to Christ’s patience—providing an example for all who are called to faith and eternal life.

verses.text: To the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only God, be honor and glory forever and ever. Amen.
verses.comment: This doxology reflects the transcendence of God and the practice of giving praise within Church liturgy.

verses.text: This charge I entrust to you, Timothy, my child, according to the prophecies previously made concerning you, that by them you may wage the good warfare,
verses.comment: References to Timothy’s ordination and prophecies point to the sacramental nature of ministry. The 'good warfare' implies ongoing spiritual struggle.

verses.text: holding faith and a good conscience. By rejecting these, some have shipwrecked their faith.
verses.comment: The link between faith and conscience is essential for authentic Christianity. Faithfulness to Church-held beliefs guards against apostasy.

verses.text: Among them are Hymenaeus and Alexander, whom I have handed over to Satan so that they may learn not to blaspheme.
verses.comment: Church discipline is exercised here, not out of malice but for their correction and possible restoration. This practice presupposes authority and the hopes of repentance and reconciliation within the community.
